If you are not using the router to resolve domain names, you could hard code it in the /etc/resolv.conf file.  But if you have a router to do it for you, I'm not sure why you're not already using it.
If you look at the resolv.conf file and see what it says for nameserver, that would give you a clue.
The router usually acts as a caching nameserver.  It acquires DNS info from an official nameserver and passes it on to your LAN.

If, for some reason, your router's nameserver is not turned on, you can use an outside nameserver, like 8.8.8.8   In that case, you just see that the nameserver line in the /etc/resolv.conf file says:  nameserver 8.8.8.8
